item.title: Recognizing the 150th anniversary of the Colorado National Guard.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Military Personnel.

item.text: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (text: CR S204)
Passed/agreed to in Senate: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent.(text: CR S204)
Senate Committee on Armed Services discharged by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S203-204)
Senate Committee on Armed Services discharged by Unanimous Consent.(consideration: CR S203-204)
Referred to the Committee on Armed Services. (text of measure as introduced: CR S155-156)

summary.text:
Recognizes the 150th anniversary of the founding of the Colorado National Guard (Guard) and its exemplary service to the state of Colorado and the nation.

Thanks Guard members and their families for their service and sacrifice on behalf of Colorado and the nation.

Pledges continued support in providing the Guard with the resources necessary to perform state and federal missions.

Expresses condolences to the families of those Guard members who made the ultimate sacrifice while serving in the Guard.

Honors the dedication of Guard members who play a central role in protecting the United States and the freedoms and liberties of its citizens.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
